means: [心]有条件的，由一定条件诱发的

sentence.Network_en: Their support is conditional on his proposals meeting their approval.
sentence.Network_cn: 他们的支持是以他的提案得到他们的批准为条件的。

sentence.Network_en: He was given a conditional discharge and ordered to pay compensation.
sentence.Network_cn: 他被有条件地释放了，被责令支付赔偿款。

sentence.Network_en: Bristol Crown Court granted conditional bail with a surety of £2,500.
sentence.Network_cn: 英国布里斯托尔刑事法庭准予有条件保释，保证金为2,500英镑。

derivation.yuyuan_name: late Middle English: from Old French condicionel or late Latin condicionalis, from condicio(n-) 'agreement' (see condition)

entry.def: If a situation or agreement is conditional on something, it will only happen or continue if this thing happens.

example.ex: Their support is conditional on his proposals meeting their approval.
example.tran: 他们的支持是以他的提案得到他们的批准为条件的。

entry.def: In grammar, a conditional clause is a subordinate clause which refers to a situation which may exist or whose possible consequences you are considering. Most conditional clauses begin with 'if' or 'unless', for example 'If that happens, we'll be in big trouble' and 'You don't have to come unless you want to'.

means.word_mean: 2. imposing or depending on or containing a condition;

sentences.sentence: "the conditional sale will not be complete until the full purchase price is paid"

auth_sentence.content: His parents' affection...was always conditional on good behaviour.

auth_sentence.content: But that money is conditional upon a tough austerity program.
auth_sentence.res_content: But that money is conditional upon a tough austerity program.

means.word_mean: 有条件的, 受制约的

sentences.en: She has been granted conditional bail.
My agreement is conditional on your help.
